{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} '''Gareth Wyn Williams''' (26 September 1978 – {{circa|16 August 2010}}) was a Welsh mathematician and employee of [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] seconded to the [[Secret Intelligence Service]] (SIS or MI6) who was found dead in suspicious circumstances at a Security Service [[safe house]] flat in [[Pimlico]], London, on 23 August 2010.<ref name="telegraph1">Gordon Rayner, Chief Reporter [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9175962/Was-MI6-spy-in-a-bag-Gareth-Williams-killed-by-secret-service-dark-arts.html "Was MI6 spy-in-a-bag Gareth Williams killed by 'secret service dark arts'?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331223416/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9175962/Was-MI6-spy-in-a-bag-Gareth-Williams-killed-by-secret-service-dark-arts.html |date=31 March 2012 }}, ''The Telegraph'', 30 March 2012.</ref> The [[Inquests in England and Wales|inquest]] found that his death was "unnatural and likely to have been criminally mediated." A subsequent [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] re-investigation<ref name=guardian-20120502/> concluded that Williams's death was "probably an accident".<ref name="bbc111313">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-24927078 "MI6 spy Gareth Williams death 'probably an accident', police say"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114000530/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-24927078 |date=14 November 2013 }}, ''BBC News'', 13 November 2013.</ref> It is also suspected that he should be numbered amongst those who have been killed by Russian assassins on British soil. Two senior British police sources have said some of Williams's work was focused on Russia – and one confirmed reports that he had been helping the NSA trace international [[money-laundering]] routes that are used by organised crime groups including Moscow-based mafia cells.<ref> secrets of the spy in the bag [https://r.search.yahoo.com/_ylt=AwrBT6MJe0pZ.YIAaMRXNyoA;_ylu=X3oDMTEyNnQ4cHI3BGNvbG8DYmYxBHBvcwMxBHZ0aWQDVUkyQzNfMQRzZWMDc3I-/RV=2/RE=1498082186/RO=10/RU=https%3a%2f%2fwww.buzzfeed.com%2ftomwarren%2fsecrets-of-the-spy-in-the-bag/RK=1/RS=jE5HYGU8M9ZVeHG5sCneH2gTJWQ- secrets of the spy in the bag]</ref> ==Background== Originally from [[Anglesey]], [[Wales]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/wales/dead-mi6-spy-is-welshman05717/ |title=Dead MI6 worker is Welsh |publisher=ITV News |date=25 August 2010 |accessdate=24 February 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830023059/http://www.itv.com/wales/dead-mi6-spy-is-welshman05717/|archivedate=30 August 2010}}</ref> Williams, who spoke [[Welsh language|Welsh]] as a first language, began studying mathematics part-time at [[Bangor University]], while still at [[Ysgol Uwchradd Bodedern]], and graduated with a first-class degree at age 17.<ref name=bbc-nww-20100826>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-north-west-wales-11095158 |title=MI6 worker Gareth Williams was an 'exceptional' pupil |date=26 August 2010 |publisher=BBC North West Wales |accessdate=2 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130823061327/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-north-west-wales-11095158 |archivedate=23 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> After gaining a PhD at the [[University of Manchester]], he dropped out from a subsequent post-graduate course at [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]],<ref>Cathy Scott-Clark and Adrian Levy [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/nov/20/gareth-williams-spy-mi6 "Who was Gareth Williams?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161212114217/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/nov/20/gareth-williams-spy-mi6 |date=12 December 2016 }} ''The Guardian'', 20 November 2010.</ref> and took up employment with GCHQ in [[Cheltenham]] in 2001,<ref name=thereg-20120502/> renting a room for a decade in [[Prestbury, Gloucestershire]]. Reportedly an intensely private man and a keen cyclist, Williams was due to return to Cheltenham at the beginning of September 2010 after his annual leave.<ref>Vikram Dodd, et al [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/25/british-spy-mi6-gareth-williams "MI6 worker murdered, stuffed in a bag and dumped in a bath"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826160710/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/25/british-spy-mi6-gareth-williams |date=26 August 2017 }}, ''The Guardian'', 25 August 2010.</ref>
==Death== [[File:GraveOfGarethWilliams.jpg|thumb|right|Gareth Williams' grave in Ynys Wen Cemetery, [[Valley, Anglesey]]. The photo has embedded GPS co-ordinates]] Police visited Williams's home during the afternoon of Monday 23 August 2010, as a "welfare check" after colleagues noted he had been out of contact for several days.<ref name="C4 News">[http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/politics/domestic_politics/family+aposdistressapos+as+mi6+probes+dead+spy+vetting/3755877 "Exclusive: new details on MI6 spy's death"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830210757/http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/politics/domestic_politics/family+aposdistressapos+as+mi6+probes+dead+spy+vetting/3755877 |date=30 August 2010 }}, Channel 4 News, 28 August 2010.</ref> His decomposing naked remains were found in a red [[The North Face]] bag, padlocked from the outside, in the bath of the main bedroom's en-suite bathroom.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/28/spy-alive-eight-days-body "Spy last seen alive eight days before body was found in bag"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161216163357/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/28/spy-alive-eight-days-body |date=16 December 2016 }}, ''The Guardian'' (Press Association), 28 August 2010.</ref><ref name=bbc-20100901>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-11152467 |title=Body of MI6 worker Gareth Williams 'locked in bag' |publisher=BBC News |date=1 September 2010 |accessdate=1 September 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100901191458/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-11152467 |archivedate=1 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The police had gained entry into his top floor flat in Alderney Street, Pimlico at around 16:40.<ref>Helen Pidd [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/25/british-spy-dead-in-bath "'British spy' found dead in bath"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161218035456/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/25/british-spy-dead-in-bath |date=18 December 2016 }}, ''The Guardian'', 25 August 2010.</ref> His family believe that crucial [[DNA]] was interfered with and that fingerprints left at the scene were wiped off as part of a [[cover-up]].<ref name="telegraph1"/> No fingerprints, palm-prints, footprints or traces of Williams's DNA were found on the rim of the bath, the bag zip or the bag padlock. A key to the padlock was inside the bag, underneath his body.<ref name="telegraph2015-10-24">{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/11952973/Spy-in-bag-Gareth-Williams-was-murdered-by-Russian-hitmen-after-sexual-photo-blackmail-plot.html | title='Spy in bag' Gareth Williams was 'murdered by Russian hitmen after sexual photo blackmail plot' | work=The Daily Telegraph | date=24 October 2015 | accessdate=25 October 2015 | author=Clarke-Billings, Lucy | location=London | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151025141219/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/11952973/Spy-in-bag-Gareth-Williams-was-murdered-by-Russian-hitmen-after-sexual-photo-blackmail-plot.html | archivedate=25 October 2015 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Williams was buried at Ynys Wen cemetery in [[Valley, Anglesey]], on 26 September 2010, following a private funeral service at Bethel Chapel in [[Holyhead]] attended by his family, friends, former colleagues in the intelligence services, and also by the head of SIS, [[John Sawers|Sir John Sawers]].<ref name=telegraph-20120422/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/2010/09/25/funeral-of-anglesey-mi6-code-breaker-gareth-williams-55578-27338999/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120731091442/http://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/2010/09/25/funeral-of-anglesey-mi6-code-breaker-gareth-williams-55578-27338999/ |archivedate=31 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} </ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Tom Pettifor |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/was-body-in-the-bag-spy-gareth-williams-betrayed-757314 |title=Was body-in-the-bag spy Gareth Williams betrayed by a double agent? – Mirror Online |publisher=Mirror.co.uk |date=10 March 2012 |accessdate=24 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130422021356/http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/was-body-in-the-bag-spy-gareth-williams-betrayed-757314 |archivedate=22 April 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Investigation== Williams's date of death was estimated to have been in the early hours of 16 August, one week before he was found.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17790563 "Profile: MI6 spy Gareth Williams"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425152411/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17790563 |date=25 April 2012 }}, ''BBC News'', 23 April 2012.</ref>
Vincent Williams from the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] informed the [[Westminster]] [[Coroner's Court]] that experts were agreed that it was impossible for Gareth Williams to have locked himself in.{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}}
Soon after the investigation started, the heads of the Secret Intelligence Service and Metropolitan Police met to discuss how the police would handle the investigation in light of the top secret nature of Williams's work, and who would lead the investigation. Williams had recently qualified for operational deployment, and had worked with U.S. [[National Security Agency]] and [[FBI]] agents. The [[U.S. State Department]] asked that no details of Williams's work should emerge at the inquest. The Foreign Secretary, [[William Hague]], signed a [[public-interest immunity]] certificate authorising the withholding from the inquest of details of Williams's work and U.S. joint operations.<ref name=telegraph-20120422>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9218325/Secret-meeting-between-MI6-and-police-hours-after-discovery-of-spy-Gareth-Williamss-death.html |title=Secret meeting between MI6 and police hours after discovery of spy Gareth Williams's death |author1=Patrick Sawer |author2=Gordon Thomas |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=27 April 2012 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425035325/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9218325/Secret-meeting-between-MI6-and-police-hours-after-discovery-of-spy-Gareth-Williamss-death.html |archivedate=25 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
After launching an investigation, the coroner Dr Fiona Wilcox said that there were no injuries on his body and no signs that he had been involved in a struggle; his body was also free of alcohol and common recreational drugs.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |last=Lutwyche |first=Jayne |url=http://itvwales.wordpress.com/2010/09/06/more-details-released-in-mi6-worker-gareth-williams-death-inquiry/ |title=Police appeal for information in MI6 worker, Gareth Williams, death inquiry |publisher=ITV |date=24 September 2010 |accessdate=2 May 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926051011/https://itvwales.wordpress.com/2010/09/06/more-details-released-in-mi6-worker-gareth-williams-death-inquiry/ |archivedate=26 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>Sam Jones and Matthew Taylor [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/aug/26/gareth-williams-mi6-officer-parents "Gareth Williams's parents identify body"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170320150004/https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/aug/26/gareth-williams-mi6-officer-parents |date=20 March 2017 }}, ''The Guardian'', 26 August 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Caroline Davies |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/sep/06/mi6-death-gareth-williams-cctv |title=Police issue CCTV footage of dead MI6 worker |publisher=Guardian |date=6 September 2010 |accessdate=2 May 2012 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114024133/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/sep/06/mi6-death-gareth-williams-cctv |archivedate=14 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The [[Metropolitan Police]] considered his death "suspicious and unexplained".<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-11093184 "More tests due on body of MI6 worker Gareth Williams"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100826061444/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-11093184 |date=26 August 2010 }}, BBC News, 26 August 2010.</ref> The FBI also conducted their own investigation into the case.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/8024998/FBI-joins-investigation-into-MI6-spys-death.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Gordon | last1=Thomas | first2=Patrick | last2=Sawer | title=FBI joins investigation into MI6 spy's death | date=25 September 2010 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100926110924/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/8024998/FBI-joins-investigation-into-MI6-spys-death.html | archivedate=26 September 2010 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In December 2010, police released further details, stating that Williams had visited a number of [[Bondage (sexual)|bondage]] websites although at the later inquest it was stated these visits were "sporadic and isolated" and accounted for only a small proportion of the time he spent online. It was also noted at the inquest that he never visited any website devoted to claustrophilia – a sexual interest in being confined in small spaces.<ref name="guardian2012-05-02">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/may/02/gareth-williams-key-unanswered-questions | title=Gareth Williams: the key unanswered questions | work=The Guardian | date=2 May 2012 | accessdate=24 October 2015 | author=Davis, Caroline | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131174437/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/may/02/gareth-williams-key-unanswered-questions | archivedate=31 January 2016 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
An expert brought in to examine the bag in which Williams's body was found concluded that Williams could not have locked it. A police spokesperson stated that: "If he was alive, he got into it voluntarily or, if not, he was unconscious and placed in the bag."<ref name=bbc20101222>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-12059910|title=Dead MI6 spy Gareth Williams 'visited bondage websites'|publisher=BBC News|date=22 December 2010|accessdate=22 December 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101223041537/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-12059910|archivedate=23 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The heating in Williams's apartment was found to be turned on.<ref name="guardian2012-05-02" /> It has been suggested an elevated temperature inside the apartment would have sped up the decomposition of Williams's body.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}}
Subsequently, the police released an [[E-FIT]] photo of two people they were seeking, who were seen to enter the communal entrance of his home in June or July 2010.<ref name=bbc20101222 />
==Coroner's inquest== The lawyer for the family, Anthony O'Toole, at the Coroner's [[Inquests in England and Wales|inquest]] in March 2012, said that a second person was either present when Williams died, or someone broke in afterwards and stole items. There is no forensic evidence to support this view. No sign of forced entry could be found, but it was also noted that the door and locks had been removed by the time police experts had become involved.
DNA found on Williams's hand turned out to be contamination from one of the forensic scientists and the police determined that a Mediterranean couple they had been seeking had nothing to do with the inquiry.<ref>{{cite news |author=Press Association |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/apr/23/spy-in-bag-death-coroners-inquest |title=Gareth Williams: coroner's inquest over spy found dead in bag |publisher=Guardian |date=23 April 2012 |accessdate=2 May 2012 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113194117/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/apr/23/spy-in-bag-death-coroners-inquest |archivedate=13 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[LGC Ltd|LGC]], the forensic company, apologised that the error had inflicted such pain on the family, caused by the incorrect data entry of a numerical code.<ref name="telegraph1"/>
Evidence at the inquest showed that it would have been virtually impossible for Williams to have locked himself in the bag.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17865736 |title=MI6 officer inquest hears claim of third party role |publisher=BBC News |date=27 April 2012 |accessdate=2 May 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430024050/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17865736 |archivedate=30 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Two experts were unable to lock themselves in a similar bag despite making 400 attempts to do so, although one stated there was a small chance Williams had managed the feat.<ref name="guardian2012-05-02" /> Pathologist Dr Richard Shepherd stated it was more likely that Williams was alive when he got into the bag, due to the difficulty of arranging a corpse in the position William's body was found in. Another pathologist stated that Williams would have been overcome by [[hypercapnia]], elevated carbon dioxide levels, after only two or three minutes in the bag.<ref name="guardian2012-05-02" />
Williams's family said they believed that a secret service agency was involved in his death.<ref>{{cite news |author=Chris Greenwood |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2122792/Secret-agents-specialising-dark-arts-covered-death-MI6-spy-holdall.html |title=Secret agents specializing in dark arts may have covered up death of MI6 spy found in holdall |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=31 March 2012 |accessdate=2 May 2012 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120730055542/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2122792/Secret-agents-specialising-dark-arts-covered-death-MI6-spy-holdall.html |archivedate=30 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Dr Fiona Wilcox, the Coroner, said that she would "follow the evidence" wherever it led.<ref name="telegraph1"/>
Evidence given by Williams's former landlady in Cheltenham showed how one night he had awoken her and her husband, screaming for help. Apparently he had managed to tie himself to his bed, and required assistance in releasing himself. The testimony was that Williams had claimed at the time that he had done it just to see if he could free himself and that he promised not to try this again. Nothing further had been said about the incident since between Williams and his landlady.<ref>Paul Cheston [http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/crime/spy-gareth-williams-tied-himself-to-bed-and-had-to-be-freed-by-landlady-7678657.html "Spy Gareth Williams 'tied himself to bed and had to be freed by landlady'"], ''Evening Standard'', 25 April 2012. Retrieved 25 April 2012.</ref>
Evidence was given of £20,000 worth of women's clothing being found in the flat.<ref>{{cite news |last=Whitehead |first=Tom |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9228651/Interest-in-womens-clothing-and-sadomasochism-would-not-have-prevented-Gareth-Williams-joining-MI6-inquest-hears.html |title=Interest in women's clothing and sadomasochism would not have prevented Gareth Williams joining MI6, inquest hears |publisher=Telegraph |date=26 April 2012 |accessdate=24 February 2013 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702224959/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9228651/Interest-in-womens-clothing-and-sadomasochism-would-not-have-prevented-Gareth-Williams-joining-MI6-inquest-hears.html |archivedate=2 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The journalist [[Duncan Campbell (journalist)|Duncan Campbell]] reported that the inquest evidence indicated Williams was one of a team of intelligence officers sent to penetrate US and UK hacking networks. He had attended the 2010 [[Black Hat Briefings]] and [[DEF CON]] conferences. He had started with SIS in London in spring 2009, and after taking a number of training courses started on "active operational work".<ref name=thereg-20120502>{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/05/03/gareth_williams_inquest/ |title=GCHQ's spy death riddle shines light on UK hacker war |author=Duncan Campbell |newspaper=The Register |date=3 May 2012 |accessdate=3 May 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505211428/http://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/05/03/gareth_williams_inquest/ |archivedate=5 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A few months before his death, he asked to return to GCHQ as he disliked the "rat race, flash car competitions and post-work drinking culture" at SIS and as a keen cyclist and walker wanted to go back to the countryside, and was due to return in September.<ref name=telegraph-20120502/>
===Inquest verdict=== The coroner found in a [[narrative verdict]] that Williams's death was "unnatural and likely to have been criminally mediated". The coroner was "satisfied that on the balance of probabilities that Gareth was killed unlawfully". There was insufficient evidence to give a verdict of [[unlawful killing]]. The coroner concluded that another party placed the bag containing Williams into the bath, and on the balance of probabilities locked the bag. No fingerprints were found around the bath. The coroner was critical of SIS for failing to report Williams missing for seven days, which caused extra anguish and suffering for his family, and led to the loss of forensic evidence.<ref name=guardian-20120502>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/may/02/gareth-williams-death-mi6 |title=MI6 and Met condemned over Gareth Williams's death |author1=Caroline Davies |author2=Sandra Laville |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2 May 2012 |accessdate=3 May 2012 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113194428/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/may/02/gareth-williams-death-mi6 |archivedate=13 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=telegraph-20120502>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9242346/Coroner-MI6-spys-death-was-probably-a-crime.html |title=Coroner: MI6 spy's death was probably a crime |author1=Tom Whitehead |author2=Martin Evans |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=2 May 2012 |accessdate=4 May 2012 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503015114/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9242346/Coroner-MI6-spys-death-was-probably-a-crime.html |archivedate=3 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=bbc-20120502>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17922388 |title=MI6 death: Gareth Williams 'probably' killed unlawfully |work=BBC News |date=2 May 2012 |accessdate=2 May 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502130819/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17922388 |archivedate=2 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The coroner rejected suicide, interest in bondage or cross-dressing, or "auto-erotic activity" being involved in Williams's death.<ref name=guardian-20120502b>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/may/02/gareth-williams-coroner-never-solved |title=Gareth Williams's death was 'criminally mediated', says coroner |author1=Caroline Davies |author2=James Meikle |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2 May 2012 |accessdate=3 May 2012 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113194347/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/may/02/gareth-williams-coroner-never-solved |archivedate=13 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> She said his visits to bondage websites only occurred intermittently and were not of a frequency to indicate an active interest.<ref name=telegraph-20120502/> The coroner condemned leaks about cross-dressing as a possible attempt at media manipulation.<ref name=guardian-20120502 />
The coroner was highly critical of the Metropolitan Police's [[Counter Terrorism Command]] (SO15), who failed to tell the senior investigating officer before the inquest began of the existence of nine memory sticks and other property in Williams's SIS office. SO15 failed to take formal statements when interviewing SIS officers. The coroner said the possible involvement of SIS staff in the death was a legitimate line of inquiry for the police.<ref name=guardian-20120502 />
==Metropolitan Police investigation==
The finding by Westminster coroner Dr Fiona Wilcox prompted a reinvestigation by the Metropolitan Police lasting a further 12 months which officers said had been allowed unprecedented access to serving MI6 staff following strong criticism at the inquest of the spying agency's actions following the death of Mr Williams.
Metropolitan Police Deputy Assistant Commissioner Martin Hewitt announced that despite a re-examination of all evidence and the investigation of new leads no definitive answers had been obtained as to the cause of Williams's death and the "most probable scenario" was that he had died alone in his flat in Pimlico, central London, as the result of accidentally locking himself inside the bag.<ref name="AP 2013">{{Cite news |title=Gareth Williams, British Spy, Likely Died in Bag By Accident , opposite of what the coroner had stated |author=Raphael Satter |date=13 November 2013 |agency=AP |newspaper=Huffington Post |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/13/gareth-williams-accident-died-in-bag_n_4266397.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113172525/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/13/gareth-williams-accident-died-in-bag_n_4266397.html |archivedate=13 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/13/mi6-spy-dead-bag-locked-himself-gareth-williams |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-12-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308072009/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/13/mi6-spy-dead-bag-locked-himself-gareth-williams |archivedate=8 March 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==2015 developments== In September and October 2015, [[Boris Karpichkov]], a former [[KGB]] agent who defected from Russia and who now lives in Britain, stated during interviews that "sources in Russia" have claimed that the Russian [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)|Foreign Intelligence Service]], also known as the SVR, was responsible for Williams's murder. According to Karpichkov, the SVR tried and failed to blackmail Williams into becoming a [[double agent]].<ref name="independent20170508">Loulla-Mae Eleftheriou-Smith (28 September 2015) [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/mi6-spy-gareth-williams-was-killed-by-russia-for-refusing-to-become-double-agent-former-kgb-man-a6670196.html MI6 spy Gareth Williams was ‘killed by Russia for refusing to become double agent’, former KGB man claims] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170508113718/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/mi6-spy-gareth-williams-was-killed-by-russia-for-refusing-to-become-double-agent-former-kgb-man-a6670196.html |date=8 May 2017 }}, ''[[The Independent]]''.</ref>
In response to the SVR's attempts, Williams apparently claimed that he knew "the identity of a Russian spy inside the GCHQ." Karpichkov claimed that Williams's threat meant that "the SVR then had no alternative but to exterminate him in order to protect their agent inside GCHQ." Regarding the cause of death, Karpichkov claimed that the SVR killed Williams "by an untraceable poison introduced in his ear."<ref>Barbara Tasch (28 September 2015) [http://www.businessinsider.com/kgb-defector-russia-killed-the-british-spy-found-in-a-duffel-bag-2015-9 KGB defector: Russia killed the British spy found in a duffel bag] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929033352/http://www.businessinsider.com/kgb-defector-russia-killed-the-british-spy-found-in-a-duffel-bag-2015-9 |date=29 September 2015 }}, ''[[Business Insider]]''.</ref><ref name="independent20170508" />

{{refimprove|date=December 2010}} '''Der Löwe''' (1944–1973) was a successful [[stallion]] who had a great impact on the breeding of [[Warmblood]]s and is thought by some to be one of the most important post-war stallions to stand at stud.[http://www.synergysporthorses.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=109%3Ader-loewe-xx&Itemid=141 Der Loewe xx ] *'''Color''': Dark brown *'''Markings''': Sock RH, Snip *'''Height''': 15.2 hh (1.58 m) *'''Sex''': [[Stallion (horse)|Stallion]] *'''Breed''': [[Thoroughbred]] (in the [[Hanoverian (horse)|Hanoverian]] and [[Holstein (horse)|Holstein]] studbooks) *'''Breeding''': by Wahnfried, out of Lehnsherrinl, by Herold *'''Breeder''': P. Mühlhens, Röttgen stud ==Breeding== Der Löwe includes in his pedigree [[Dark Ronald]], son of [[Bay Ronald]], both of whom are well known for their profound influence on the breeding of warmbloods. Dark Ronald was successful on the track and in the breeding shed in Britain, before being shipped to the German state stud of Graditz. In Germany, Dark Ronald went on to become one of the most prolific stallions ever imported, producing sons such as [[Prunus (horse)|Prunus]], [[Herold (horse)|Herold]], and Wallenstein. Der Löwe's sire, Wahnfried, was the winner of the German St. Leger. Wahnfried's pedigree includes 1903 [[English Triple Crown]] winner [[Rock Sand]], who was also grand-sire to [[Man o' War (horse)|Man o' War]]. Great-grandsire [[Tracery (horse)|Tracery]] won the [[St. Leger]] and sired many excellent racehorses in Britain. '''Pedigree for Der Löwe'''

b. 1913 |ffff = [[Rock Sand]] |fffm = Topiary |ffmf = [[St. Simon (horse)|St. Simon]] |ffmm = Philomath |fmff = Wiesenbaum |fmfm = Elfe |fmmf = Waidmannsdank |fmmm = Maigold |mfff = [[Bay Ronald]] |mffm = Darkie |mfmf = Ard Patrick |mfmm = Hortensia |mmff = [[Galtee More]] |mmfm = Festa |mmmf = Marta Santa |mmmm = Line of Life |}} ==Performance and breeding career== Der Löwe was used as a [[racehorse]] for the first years of his life, and was a successful stakes winner, most notably winning the [[Grosser Preis von Baden]] in 1948. He was then sent to the [[Hanoverian (horse)|Hanoverian]] stud at Grossenworden at the age of 7, to begin his breeding career. Der Löwe stood at Grossenworden from 1951 to 1961, before standing at Luhmühlen from 1962 to 1968, Otterstedt from 1969 to 1971, Sottrum in 1972, and Bargstedt in 1973. His breeding career spanned 20 years, during which time he produced 6 state stallions, 158 registered mares, as well as 314 competition horses who earned winning of DM750,000. In his career, Der Löwe produced many international-caliber [[sport horse]]s, known for their expressive movement (although they were usually quite sensitive to sound). [[Show jumping|Show jumpers]] included Der Lord and Loriot, both ridden by Hartwig Steenken. In eventing, Löwenstern was very successful with Nils Haagensen. He also sired [[dressage]] horses such as Karin Schlüter's Liostro, Erika Scharzkopf's Löwenherz, Carola Lampe's Lanthan, Holger& Inge Schmezers' Lady Lou, Hans-Jürgen Armbrust's Leopardin, Marjolyn Greeve's Lucky Boy, John Winnett's and Leopardi. Perhaps most known were Lugano I and Lugano II, full-brothers sired by Der Lowe. Lugano I sired good [[dressage]] horses, as well as superb [[show jumping|show jumpers]]. Lugano II produced the stallion Lombard, making him grand-sire to Lanthan and Leubus. Although 10 of his grandsons or great-grandsons stood at the Celle Stud in the 1980s, his influence has been slowly decreasing. He has had a more lasting impact on the breeding of Belgian jumpers, through his grandson Lugano van la Roche. Additionally, he is one of only a handful of Hanoverian stallions licensed by the Holstein Verband for breeding. Der Löwe died at the age of 29. His skeleton is displayed at the Verden horse museum. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Der Lowe}} [[Category:Sport horse sires]] [[Category:1944 animal births]] [[Category:1973 animal deaths]] [[Category:Hanoverian horses]] [[Category:Individual warmbloods]] [[Category:Thoroughbred horses]]

[[File:Exciton.png|thumbnail|Frenkel exciton, bound electron-hole pair where the hole is localized at a position in the crystal represented by black dots]] [[File:Moving Wannier exciton.svg|thumbnail|Wannier-Mott exciton, bound electron-hole pair that is not localized at a crystal position. This figure schematically shows diffusion of the exciton across the lattice.]]
{{Condensed matter physics|expanded=Quasiparticles}} An '''exciton''' is a [[bound state]] of an [[electron]] and an [[electron hole]] which are attracted to each other by the electrostatic [[Coulomb's law|Coulomb force]]. It is an electrically neutral [[quasiparticle]] that exists in [[Electrical insulation|insulators]], [[semiconductor]]s and in some liquids. The exciton is regarded as an elementary excitation of [[condensed matter]] that can transport energy without transporting net electric charge.<ref>R. S. Knox, Theory of excitons, Solid state physics (Ed. by Seitz and Turnbul, Academic, NY), v. 5, 1963.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1088/0031-9120/5/4/003|title=Excitons|year=1970|last1=Liang|first1=W Y|journal=Physics Education|volume=5|issue=125301 |pages=226-228|bibcode = 1970PhyEd...5..226L }}</ref>
An exciton can form when a [[photon]] is absorbed by a semiconductor.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.84.125301|title=Charge control in InP/(Ga,In)P single quantum dots embedded in Schottky diodes|year=2011|last1=Couto|first1=ODD|last2=Puebla|first2=J|journal=Physical Review B|volume=84|page=226|bibcode = 1970PhyEd...5..226L|issue=4 |arxiv=1107.2522}}</ref> This excites an electron from the [[valence band]] into the [[conduction band]]. In turn, this leaves behind a positively charged [[electron hole]] (an abstraction for the location from which an electron was moved). The electron in the conduction band is then effectively attracted to this localized hole by the repulsive [[Coulomb force]]s from large numbers of electrons surrounding the hole and excited electron. This attraction provides a stabilizing energy balance. Consequently, the exciton has slightly less energy than the unbound electron and hole. The [[wavefunction]] of the bound state is said to be ''[[Hydrogen-like atom|hydrogenic]]'', an [[exotic atom]] state akin to that of a [[hydrogen]] [[atom]]. However, the [[binding energy]] is much smaller and the particle's size much larger than a hydrogen atom. This is because of both the screening of the Coulomb force by other electrons in the semiconductor (i.e., its [[dielectric constant]]), and the small [[effective mass (solid-state physics)|effective mass]]es of the excited electron and hole. The recombination of the electron and hole, i.e. the decay of the exciton, is limited by resonance stabilization due to the overlap of the electron and hole wave functions, resulting in an extended lifetime for the exciton.
The electron and hole may have either parallel or anti-parallel [[Spin (physics)|spin]]s. The spins are coupled by the [[exchange interaction]], giving rise to exciton [[fine structure]]. In periodic lattices, the properties of an exciton show [[Crystal momentum|momentum]] (k-vector) dependence.
The concept of excitons was first proposed by [[Yakov Frenkel]] in 1931,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.37.17|title=On the Transformation of light into Heat in Solids. I|year=1931|last1=Frenkel|first1=J.|journal=Physical Review|volume=37|issue=1|page=17|bibcode = 1931PhRv...37...17F }}</ref> when he described the excitation of atoms in a lattice of insulators. He proposed that this excited state would be able to travel in a particle-like fashion through the lattice without the net transfer of charge.
==Classification== Excitons may be treated in two limiting cases, depending on the properties of the material in question.
===Frenkel excitons=== In materials with a relatively small [[dielectric constant]], the Coulomb interaction between an electron and a hole may be strong and the excitons thus tend to be small, of the same order as the size of the unit cell. Molecular excitons may even be entirely located on the same molecule, as in [[fullerene]]s. This ''Frenkel exciton'', named after [[Yakov Frenkel]], has a typical binding energy on the order of 0.1 to 1 [[electron volt|eV]]. Frenkel excitons are typically found in alkali halide crystals and in organic molecular crystals composed of aromatic molecules, such as [[anthracene]] and [[tetracene]].
===Wannier–Mott excitons=== In semiconductors, the dielectric constant is generally large. Consequently, [[electric field screening]] tends to reduce the Coulomb interaction between electrons and holes. The result is a ''Wannier exciton'',<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.52.191|title=The Structure of Electronic Excitation Levels in Insulating Crystals|year=1937|last1=Wannier|first1=Gregory|journal=Physical Review|volume=52|page=191|bibcode = 1937PhRv...52..191W|issue=3 }}</ref> which has a radius larger than the lattice spacing. Small effective mass of electrons that is typical of semiconductors also favors large exciton radii. As a result, the effect of the lattice potential can be incorporated into the effective masses of the electron and hole. Likewise, because of the lower masses and the screened Coulomb interaction, the binding energy is usually much less than that of a hydrogen atom, typically on the order of {{gaps|0.01|eV}}. This type of exciton was named for [[Gregory Wannier]] and [[Nevill Francis Mott]]. Wannier-Mott excitons are typically found in semiconductor crystals with small energy gaps and high dielectric constants, but have also been identified in liquids, such as liquid [[xenon]]. They are also known as ''large excitons''.
In single-wall [[carbon nanotubes]], excitons have both Wannier-Mott and Frenkel character. This is due to the nature of the Coulomb interaction between electrons and holes in one-dimension. The dielectric function of the nanotube itself is large enough to allow for the spatial extent of the [[wave function]] to extend over a few to several nanometers along the tube axis, while poor screening in the vacuum or dielectric environment outside of the nanotube allows for large (0.4 to {{gaps|1.0|eV}}) binding energies.
Often there is more than one band to choose from for the electron and the hole leading to different types of excitons in the same material. Even high-lying bands can be effective as [[femtosecond]] two-photon experiments have shown. At cryogenic temperatures, many higher excitonic levels can be observed approaching the edge of the band,<ref>http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v514/n7522/full/nature13832.html</ref> forming a series of spectral absorption lines that are in principle similar to [[hydrogen spectral series]].
===Charge-transfer excitons=== {{expand section|date=December 2014}} An intermediate case between Frenkel and Wannier excitons, ''charge-transfer excitons'' (sometimes called simply ''CT excitons'') occur when the electron and the hole occupy adjacent molecules.<ref>{{cite book|title=Molecular Crystals|author=J. D. Wright|url={{Google books|7sroAgMASIEC|Molecular Crystals|page=108|plainurl=yes}}|page=108|edition=2nd|year=1995|orig-year=First published 1987|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-47730-7}}</ref> They occur primarily in ionic crystals.<ref>{{cite book|title=Luminescence Spectroscopy of Superconductors|author=Ivan Pelant, Jan Valenta|url={{Google books|CqD5HjFyWsMC|Luminescence Spectroscopy of Superconductors|page=161|plainurl=yes}}|page=161|year=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-958833-6}}</ref> Unlike Frenkel and Wannier excitons they display a static [[electric dipole moment]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Photophysics Behind Photovoltaics and Photonics|author=Guglielmo Lanzani|url={{Google books|RVyvgKo0lGQC|The Photophysics Behind Photovoltaics and Photonics|page=82|plainurl=yes}}|page=82|year=2012|publisher=Wiley-VCH Verlag}}</ref>
===Surface excitons=== At surfaces it is possible for so called ''image states'' to occur, where the hole is inside the solid and the electron is in the vacuum. These electron-hole pairs can only move along the surface.
===Atomic and molecular excitons=== Alternatively, an exciton may be an excited state of an atom, [[ion]], or molecule, the excitation wandering from one cell of the lattice to another.
When a molecule absorbs a quantum of energy that corresponds to a transition from one [[molecular orbital]] to another molecular orbital, the resulting electronic excited state is also properly described as an exciton. An [[electron]] is said to be found in the [[HOMO/LUMO|lowest unoccupied orbital]] and an [[electron hole]] in the [[HOMO/LUMO|highest occupied molecular orbital]], and since they are found within the same molecular orbital manifold, the electron-hole state is said to be bound. Molecular excitons typically have characteristic lifetimes on the order of [[nanoseconds]], after which the ground electronic state is restored and the molecule undergoes photon or [[phonon]] emission. Molecular excitons have several interesting properties, one of which is energy transfer (see [[Förster resonance energy transfer]]) whereby if a molecular exciton has proper energetic matching to a second molecule's spectral absorbance, then an exciton may transfer (''hop'') from one molecule to another. The process is strongly dependent on intermolecular distance between the species in solution, and so the process has found application in sensing and ''molecular rulers''.
The hallmark of molecular excitons in organic molecular crystals are doublets and/or triplets of exciton absorption bands strongly polarized along crystallographic axes. In these crystals an elementary cell includes several molecules sitting in symmetrically identical positions, which results in the level degeneracy that is lifted by intermolecular interaction. As a result, absorption bands are polarized along the symmetry axes of the crystal. Such multiplets were discovered by [[Antonina Prikhot'ko]]<ref>A. Prikhotjko, Absorption Spectra of Crystals at Low Temperatures, J. Physics USSR '''8''', 257 (1944)</ref><ref>A. F. Prikhot'ko, Izv, AN SSSR Ser. Fiz. '''7''', 499 (1948) http://ujp.bitp.kiev.ua/files/journals/53/si/53SI18p.pdf</ref> and their genesis was proposed by Alexander Davydov. It is known as 'Davydov splitting'.<ref>A.S Davydov, Theory of Molecular Excitons (Plenum, NY) 1971</ref><ref>V. L. Broude, E. I. Rashba, and E. F. Sheka, Spectroscopy of molecular excitons (Springer, NY) 1985</ref>
===Giant oscillator strength of bound excitons===
Excitons are lowest excited states of the electronic subsystem of pure crystals. Impurities can bind excitons, and when the bound state is shallow, the oscillator strength for producing bound excitons is so high that impurity absorption can compete with intrinsic exciton absorption even at rather low impurity concentrations. This phenomenon is generic and applicable both to the large radius (Wannier-Mott) excitons and molecular (Frenkel) excitons. Hence, excitons bound to impurities and defects possess [[giant oscillator strength]].<ref>E. I. Rashba, Giant Oscillator Strengths Associated with Exciton Complexes, Sov. Phys. Semicond. '''8''', 807-816 (1975)</ref>
=== Self-trapping of excitons===
In crystals excitons interact with phonons, the lattice vibrations. If this coupling is weak as in typical semiconductors such as GaAs or Si, excitons are scattered by phonons. However, when the coupling is strong, excitons can be self-trapped.<ref>N. Schwentner, E.-E. Koch, and J. Jortner, Electronic excitations in condensed rare gases, Springer tracts in modern physics, '''107''', 1 (1985).</ref><ref>M. Ueta, H. Kanzaki, K. Kobayashi, Y. Toyozawa, and E. Hanamura. Excitonic Processes in Solids, Springer Series in Solid State Sciences, Vol. '''60''' (1986).</ref> '''Self-trapping''' results in dressing excitons with a dense cloud of virtual phonons which strongly suppresses the ability of excitons to move across the crystal. In simpler terms, this means a local deformation of the crystal lattice around the exciton. Self-trapping can be achieved only if the energy of this deformation can compete with the width of the exciton band. Hence, it should be of atomic scale, of about an electron volt.
Self-trapping of excitons is similar to forming strong-coupling [[polaron]]s but with three essential differences. First, self-trapped exciton states are always of a small radius, of the order of lattice constant, due to their electric neutrality. Second, there exists a '''self-trapping barrier''' separating free and self-trapped states, hence, free excitons are metastable. Third, this barrier enables '''coexistence of free and self-trapped states''' of excitons.<ref>E. I. Rashba, "Theory of Strong Interaction of Electron Excitations with Lattice Vibrations in Molecular Crystals, Optika i Spektroskopiya '''2''', 75, 88 (1957).</ref><ref>E. I. Rashba, Self-trapping of excitons, in: Excitons (North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1982), p. 547.</ref> This means that spectral lines of free excitons and wide bands of self-trapped excitons can be seen simultaneously in absorption and luminescence spectra. While the self-trapped states are of lattice-spacing scale, the barrier has typically much larger scale. Indeed, its spatial scale is about <math>r_b\sim m\gamma^2/\omega^2</math> where <math>m</math> is effective mass of the exciton, <math>\gamma</math> is the exciton-phonon coupling constant, and <math>\omega</math> is the characteristic frequency of optical phonons. Excitons are self-trapped when <math>m</math> and <math>\gamma</math> are large, and then the spatial size of the barrier is large compared with the lattice spacing. Transforming a free exciton state into a self-trapped one proceeds as a collective tunneling of coupled exciton-lattice system (an [[instanton]]). Because <math>r_b</math> is large, tunneling can be described by a continuum theory.<ref>A. S. Ioselevich and E. I. Rashba, Theory of Nonradiative Trapping in Crystals, in: "Quantum tunneling in condensed media." Eds. Yu. Kagan and A. J. Leggett. (North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1992), p. 347-425.https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=ElDtL9qZuHUC&oi=fnd&pg=PA347&dq=%22E+I+Rashba%22&ots=KjE3JYn9kl&sig=0Aj4IdVj0zqPSyq3ep_RT6sOlgQ#v=onepage&q=%22E%20I%20Rashba%22&f=false</ref> The height of the barrier <math>W\sim \omega^4/m^3\gamma^4</math>. Because both <math>m</math> and <math>\gamma</math> appear in the denominator of <math>W</math>, the barriers are basically low. Therefore, free excitons can be seen in crystals with strong exciton-phonon coupling only in pure samples and at low temperatures. Coexistence of free and self-trapped excitons was observed in rare-gas solids,<ref>U. M. Grassano, "Excited-State Spectroscopy in Solids", ''Proceedings of the International School of Physics "Enrico Fermi", Course 96, Varenna, Italy, 9-19 July 1985.'' Amsterdam;New York: North-Holland (1987). {{ISBN|9780444870704}}, [https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/1269574].</ref><ref>I. Ya. Fugol', "Free and self-trapped excitons in cryocrystals: kinetics and relaxation processes." Advances in Physics '''37''', 1-35 (1988).</ref> alkali-halides,<ref>Ch. B. Lushchik, in "Excitons," edited by E. I. Rashba, and M. D. Sturge, (North Holland, Amsterdam, 1982), p. 505.</ref> and in molecular crystal of pyrene.<ref>M. Furukawa, Ken-ichi Mizuno, A. Matsui, N. Tamai and I. Yamazaiu, Branching of Exciton Relaxation to the Free and Self-Trapped Exciton States, Chemical Physics '''138''', 423 (1989).</ref>
===Interaction=== Excitons are the main mechanism for [[light emission]] in semiconductors at low [[temperature]] (when the characteristic thermal energy ''[[Boltzmann constant|k]]T'' is less than the exciton [[binding energy]]), replacing the free electron-hole recombination at higher temperatures.
The existence of exciton states may be inferred from the absorption of light associated with their excitation. Typically, excitons are observed just below the [[band gap]].
When excitons interact with photons a so-called [[polariton]] (also [[exciton-polaritons]]) is formed. These excitons are sometimes referred to as ''dressed excitons''.
Provided the interaction is attractive, an exciton can bind with other excitons to form a [[biexciton]], analogous to a dihydrogen [[molecule]]. If a large density of excitons is created in a material, they can interact with one another to form an [[Carrier generation and recombination|electron-hole]] liquid, a state observed in k-space indirect semiconductors.
{{anchor|excitonium}}<!-- Used by redirect -->Additionally, excitons are integer-spin particles obeying [[Bosons|Bose]] statistics in the low-density limit. In some systems, where the interactions are repulsive, a [[Bose–Einstein condensate|Bose–Einstein condensed state]], called excitonium, is predicted to be the ground state. Some evidence of excitonium has existed since the 1970s, but has often been difficult to discern from a Peierls phase.<ref>{{cite news|title=New form of matter 'excitonium' discovered|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/science/new-form-of-matter-excitonium-discovered/articleshow/61994947.cms|accessdate=10 December 2017|work=The Times of India}}</ref> Exciton condensates have allegedly been seen in a double quantum well systems.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Exciton Condensation in Bilayer Quantum Hall Systems|last = |first = |date = January 10, 2014|journal = Annual Review of Condensed Matter Physics|volume = 5|pages = 159-181|doi = 10.1146/annurev-conmatphys-031113-133832|pmid = |last1 = Eisenstein|first1 = J.P.|arxiv = 1306.0584}}</ref> In 2017 Kogar et al. found "compelling evidence" for observed excitons condensing in the three-dimensional semimetal 1T-TiSe2<ref>.{{cite journal|doi=10.1126/science.aam6432|pmid=29217574|title=Signatures of exciton condensation in a transition metal dichalcogenide|year=2017|journal=Science|volume=358|issue=6368|pages=1314–1317|arxiv=1611.04217|bibcode=2017Sci...358.1314K|last1=Kogar|first1=Anshul|last2=Rak|first2=Melinda S|last3=Vig|first3=Sean|last4=Husain|first4=Ali A|last5=Flicker|first5=Felix|last6=Joe|first6=Young Il|last7=Venema|first7=Luc|last8=MacDougall|first8=Greg J|last9=Chiang|first9=Tai C|last10=Fradkin|first10=Eduardo|last11=Van Wezel|first11=Jasper|last12=Abbamonte|first12=Peter}}</ref>
===Spatially direct and indirect excitons=== Normally, excitons in a semiconductor have a very short lifetime due to the close proximity of the electron and hole. However, by placing the electron and hole in spatially separated quantum wells with an insulating barrier layer in between so called 'spatially indirect' excitons can be created. In contrast to ordinary (spatially direct), these spatially indirect excitons can have large spatial separation between the electron and hole, and thus possess a much longer lifetime. This is often used to cool excitons to very low temperatures in order to study Bose–Einstein condensation (or rather its two-dimensional analog).<ref>[http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v483/n7391/full/nature10903.html A. A. High (2012) "Spontaneous coherence in a cold exciton gas" Nature]</ref>

[[File:German States Brunswick-Lüneburg 1679 6 Thaler D-LS214.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|6 Sterbethaler [[John Frederick, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] († 1679); obv.: monogram JF in laurel wreath, rev.: Death as a skeleton, breaking the fronds off a palm tree ([[:de:Gerhard Welter|We.]] 1692)]] {{Multiple image |image1=1-4 Sterbethaler 1727 Georg I(Vs)-2740.jpg |image2=1-4 Sterbethaler 1727 Georg I(Rs)-2739.jpg |width=130 |footer=1/4 Sterbethaler [[George I of Great Britain]] as [[prince-elector]] of the [[Electorate of Brunswick-Lüneburg]] († 1727); obv.: portrait from the right, rev.: biography in Latin ([[:de:Gerhard Welter|We.]] 2254)|||}} The term '''funeral coin''' is used for coins issued on the occasion of the death of a prominent person, mostly a ruling prince or a coin-lord. The obverse of such a coin usually depicts the [[portrait]] of the deceased; the reverse may show the [[coat of arms]] and important biographic data.<ref Name="Schmieder">Carl Christoph Schmieder: ''Handwörterbuch der gesammten Münzkunde für Münzliebhaber und Geschäftsleute.'' Buchhandlung des Hallischen Waisenhauses, Halle 1811</ref>
The first issues regarded as funeral coins were struck in [[Germany]] in the late 12th century upon the death of [[Albert the Bear]] († 1170) and [[Wichmann von Seeburg|Archbishop Wichmann]] († 1192) of [[Magdeburg]]. Around the middle of the 16th century, funeral coins were issued in some states of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. Their minting was frequent until the end of the eighteenth century, especially in the [[Electorate of Saxony]] and the [[Electorate of Brunswick-Lüneburg]]; in [[Prussia]], on the other hand, there were only a few funeral coins, so in 1713 on the occasion of the death of King [[Frederick I of Prussia|Frederick I]] and 1786 after the death of [[Frederick the Great]].<ref>Ferdinand Friedensburg: ''Deutsche Münzgeschichte.'' In: Aloys Meister (Hrsg.): ''Grundriss der Geschichtswissenschaft.'' Band 1, Abteilung 4. 2. Auflage. B. G. Teubner, Leipzig und Berlin 1912, S. 98-132</ref><ref>Friedrich von Schrötter et al. (ed.): ''Wörterbuch der Münzkunde.'' 2. unveränderte Auflage. de Gruyter, Berlin 1970, Reprint 2012, {{ISBN|978-3-11-001227-9}} (Nachdruck der Originalausgabe von 1930), Lemma "Begräbnis- oder Sterbemünzen".</ref><ref>Colin R. Bruce, Fred J. Borgmann und Elizabeth A. Burgert (eds.): ''Standard Catalog of German Coins. 1601 to present, including colonial issues. 2nd Edition.'' Krause Publications, Iola (WI), USA 1998, {{ISBN|0-87341-644-9}}.</ref>
Usually, funeral coins are [[commemorative coin]]s of precious metals with high nominal values, but there are also funeral coins as [[currency money]]. Frequently the coins are designated according to their type with (German) terms like ''Sterbet(h)aler'', ''Sterbegulden'', ''Sterbedukaten'' or ''Sterbegroschen''.<ref Name="Schmieder" />

{|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=Japanese submarine I-175 in 1941.jpg |Ship caption=Japanese submarine I-175 in 1941 }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header=I-175 |Ship country=[[Empire of Japan]] |Ship flag={{Shipboxflag|Empire of Japan|naval}} |Ship name=''I-75'' |Ship ordered=1934 |Ship builder = [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries]], Kobe |Ship laid down=1 November 1934 |Ship launched=16 September 1937 |Ship commissioned=8 December 1938 |Ship in service= |Ship struck=10 July 1944 |Ship renamed=''I-175'', 1942 |Ship fate=Sunk by destroyers, 4 February 1944 |Ship status= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class=[[Kaidai type submarine|''Kaidai'' type]] (KD6B Type) |Ship displacement=*{{Convert|1810|LT|t|0|disp=flip}} surfaced *{{Convert|2564|LT|t|0|disp=flip}} submerged |Ship length={{convert|105|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|8.2|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|4.57|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship power=*{{convert|9000|bhp|lk=in|abbr=on}} (diesels) *{{convert|1800|hp|abbr=on}} (electric motors) |Ship propulsion=*[[Diesel-electric]] *2 × [[diesel engine]]s *2 × [[electric motor]]s |Ship speed=*{{convert|23|kn|lk=in}} surfaced *{{convert|8|kn}} submerged |Ship range=*{{convert|10000|nmi|abbr=on|lk=in}} at {{convert|16|kn}} surfaced *{{convert|65|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{convert|3|kn}} submerged |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth={{convert|75|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship complement=70 |Ship armament=*6 × {{convert|533|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} [[torpedo tube]]s (4 bow, 2 stern) *1 × [[Type 3 120 mm 45 caliber naval gun|{{convert|120|mm|in|abbr=on}}]] [[deck gun]] *2 × single [[Hotchkiss M1929 machine gun|{{convert|13.2|mm|in|abbr=on}}]] [[anti-aircraft machinegun]] }} |} The '''Japanese submarine ''I-175''''' ('''''I-75''''', until 20 May 1942) was a [[Kaidai type submarine|''Kaidai'' type]] of [[cruiser submarine]] of the KD6B [[ship class|sub-class]], built for the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] (IJN) during the mid-1930s.
==Design and description== The submarines of the KD6B sub-class were essentially repeats of the preceding KD6A sub-class. They [[Displacement (ship)|displaced]] {{Convert|1785|LT|t|0|disp=flip}} surfaced and {{Convert|2564|LT|t|0|disp=flip}} submerged. The submarines were {{convert|105|m|ftin|sp=us}} long, had a [[beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|8.2|m|ftin|sp=us}} and a [[draft (hull)|draft]] of {{convert|4.57|m|ftin|sp=us}}. The boats had a diving depth of {{convert|75|m|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name=cd3>Carpenter & Polmar, p. 96</ref>
For surface running, the boats were powered by two {{convert|4500|bhp|lk=in|0|adj=on}} [[diesel engine]]s, each driving one [[propeller shaft]]. When submerged each propeller was driven by a {{convert|900|hp|0|adj=on}} [[electric motor]]. They could reach {{convert|23|kn|lk=in}} on the surface and {{convert|8|kn}} underwater.<ref name=c5>Chesneau, p. 198</ref> On the surface, the KD3Bs had a range of {{convert|10000|nmi|lk=in}} at {{convert|16|kn}}; submerged, they had a range of {{convert|65|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{convert|3|kn}}.<ref name=b4/>
The boats were armed with six internal {{convert|53.3|cm|in|1|abbr=on|sp=us}} [[torpedo tube]]s, four in the bow and two in the stern. They carried a total of 14 [[torpedo]]es. They were also armed with one [[Type 3 120 mm 45 caliber naval gun|{{convert|120|mm|in|abbr=on}}]] [[deck gun]] for combat on the surface and two [[Hotchkiss M1929 machine gun|{{convert|13.2|mm|in|abbr=on}}]] [[anti-aircraft machinegun]]s.<ref name=b4>Bagnasco, p. 183</ref>
==Career== ''I-175'' participated in the [[Attack on Pearl Harbor]] and sank the 3,252-ton American merchant ''Manini'' on 17 December 1941, 180 miles south of Hawaii. In July 1942 she operated off the eastern coast of Australia and sank the French merchant vessel ''Cagou'', the Australian trawler [[Attack on the Dureenbee|''Dureenbee'']] and damaged the Australian merchant vessels ''Allara'' and ''Murada''. ''I-175'' was depth charged by [[HMAS Cairns (J183)|HMAS ''Cairns'']] on 26 July 1942 and evaded destruction.
On 12 August, the submarine was damaged by aircraft from [[USS Enterprise (CV-6)|USS ''Enterprise'']] and needed repairs at [[Rabaul]]. ''I-175'' was damaged in a collision with the oiler ''Nisshin Maru'' on 20 November 1942 at [[Chuuk Lagoon|Truk]] and run aground to prevent from sinking. The submarine required repairs at [[Yokosuka, Kanagawa|Yokosuka]].
''I-175'' is best known for sinking Escort carrier [[USS Liscome Bay (CVE-56)|USS ''Liscome Bay'']] on 24 November 1943, killing 54 officers and 648 enlisted men.
''I-175'' was herself sunk 2 months later on 4 February 1944, during the [[Battle of Kwajalein]], when she was attacked by destroyers [[USS Charrette (DD-581)|USS ''Charrette'']] and [[USS Fair (DE-35)|''Fair'']]. ''Fair'' fired several grenades from her [[Hedgehog (weapon)|Hedgehog anti-submarine mortar]] at the Japanese submarine and sank her with the entire crew at position ({{coord|6|48|N|168|8|E}}).

{{Refimprove|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox military person |name= John Charles England |birth_date= {{birth date|1920|12|11}} |death_date= {{death date and age|1941|12|7|1920|12|11}} |birth_place= [[Harris, Missouri]] |death_place= [[Pearl Harbor]] |laceofburial= |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |image= |caption= John C. England |nickname= |allegiance= {{flag|United States of America|1912}} |branch={{flag|United States Navy}} |serviceyears= 1940–1941 |rank= [[Ensign (rank)|Ensign]] |commands= |unit= [[USS Oklahoma (BB-37)|USS ''Oklahoma'' (BB-37)]] |battles=[[World War II]] *[[Attack on Pearl Harbor]]{{KIA}} |awards= |laterwork= }} [[Ensign (rank)|Ensign]] '''John Charles England''' (December 11, 1920 – December 7, 1941) was an officer in the [[United States Navy]]. ==Biography== John Charles England was born in [[Harris, Missouri]], on December 11, 1920. His family then moved to [[Alhambra, California]]. He attended [[Alhambra High School (Alhambra, California)|Alhambra High School]], as did his sister Lennie England (Bemiss). He was president of his graduating class in 1938, acted in the senior play, was a member of the Light and Shadow drama club and Senior Hi-Y. He was voted Yell King of his senior class according to his sister Lennie. He later attended [[Pasadena City College]], [[Pasadena, California]] graduating in 1940. He was a Yell King on the Pep Commission, a member of the Players Guild, where he was in the cast of their annual fall presentation of, "Bachelor Born." He was also a member of [[Alpha Psi Omega|Delta Psi Omega]], a national honorary dramatics fraternity performing in their annual spring production, "Outward Bound." J.C. graduated in spring, 1940. He enlisted in the [[United States Naval Reserve]] as an Apprentice Seaman at Los Angeles on September 6, 1940. After active duty training on board {{USS|New York|BB-34|6}} from November 25, to December 21, 1940 he attended Naval Reserve Midshipman's School, New York, N.Y. and was appointed Midshipman, USNR, March 6, 1941. He completed his training on June 5 and was commissioned Ensign, USNR, June 6, 1941. He was next assigned duty under instruction at the Naval Radio School, Norton Heights, [[Connecticut]], reporting June 20, 1941. Upon detachment from school, he reported on September 3, 1941 to {{USS|Oklahoma|BB-37|6}} at Pearl Harbor. During this period he had also married and in early December he was eagerly awaiting the arrival of his wife and three-week-old daughter (Victoria Louise England) who were due to arrive in a few days. He had never seen his daughter. On the morning of December 7, 1941, just four days from his 21st birthday John C. England volunteered to work in the ship's radio room for a friend so that he might have more time with his family when they arrived. That morning the Japanese [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|attacked Pearl Harbor]] and USS ''Oklahoma'' was one of their first targets. ''Oklahoma'' was moored at Battleship Row 7, outboard alongside {{USS|Maryland|BB-46|6}}. USS ''Oklahoma'' took 3 torpedo hits almost immediately after the first Japanese bombs fell. As she began to capsize, 2 more torpedoes struck home, and her men were strafed as they abandoned ship. Within 20 minutes after the attack began, she had swung over until halted by her masts touching bottom, her starboard side above water, and a part of her keel clear. England survived the attack and was able to venture into the ship three consecutive times, each time leading a shipmate to safety, but died during a fourth attempt.{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/39476681/john-charles-england|title=John Charles England|publisher=findagrave.com|accessdate=24 September 2018}} His unidentified remains were buried at the [[National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific|National Cemetery]] in Hawaii. 75 years later his remains were identified and he was reburied in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]] next to his parents.{{Cite web|url=http://www.9news.com/news/local/pearl-harbor-hero-buried-in-colorado-springs/297251935|title=Pearl Harbor hero buried in Colorado Springs|last=TEGNA|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-14}}{{dead link|date=August 2016}} ==Namesakes and honors== Two ships have been named {{USS|England}} for him. In 1943, {{USS|England|DE-635}} was named to honor John Charles England. His mother Thelma cracked the ceremonial bottle of champagne on ''England'' 's bow in [[San Francisco Bay|San Francisco Harbor]] on September 26, 1943. Lennie England served as maid of honor and kept the ribbon wrapped bottle until her death in 1995. The second ship to bear the name, {{USS|England|DLG-22}} was launched in 1962. [[Alhambra High School (Alhambra, California)|Alhambra High School]] continues to award the John C. England award to their most outstanding senior each year. BEQ 836 at NSTC Great Lakes is also named in honor of England. ==Military Awards==

This is a list of words and phrases related to [[death]] in alphabetical order. While some of them are [[slang]], others euphemize the unpleasantness of the subject, or are used in formal contexts. Some of the phrases may carry the meaning of 'kill', or simply contain words related to death. Most of them are [[idioms]]. {{Dynamic list}} {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! Expression ! Count of Barcelona]] | reign = 19 May 1396 – 31 May 1410 | coronation = | predecessor = [[John I of Aragon|John I]] | successor = [[Ferdinand I of Aragon|Ferdinand I]] | succession1 = [[King of Sicily]] | reign1 = 25 July 1409 – 31 May 1410 | coronation1 = | predecessor1 = [[Martin I of Sicily|Martin I]] | successor1 = [[Ferdinand I of Aragon|Ferdinand I]] | spouse = [[Maria de Luna]]
[[Margaret of Prades]] | issue = [[Martin I of Sicily]] | issue-link = #Issue | issue-pipe = more... | house = [[House of Barcelona]] | father = [[Peter IV of Aragon]] | mother = [[Eleanor of Sicily]] | birth_date = 29 July 1356 | birth_place = [[Girona]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1410|5|31|1356|7|29|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Barcelona]] | burial_date = | burial_place = [[Poblet Monastery]] | religion = [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]] | signature = Signatura-marti-huma.jpg }} '''Martin the Humane''' (29 July 1356 – 31 May 1410), also called '''the Elder''' and '''the Ecclesiastic''', was [[King of Aragon]], [[King of Valencia|Valencia]], [[King of Sardinia|Sardinia]] and [[Medieval Corsica|Corsica]] and [[Count of Barcelona]] from 1396 and [[King of Sicily]] from 1409 (as '''Martin II'''). He failed to secure the accession of his illegitimate grandson, [[Frederic, Count of Luna]], and with him the rule of the [[House of Barcelona]] came to an end. ==Background== Martin was born in 1356, in either [[Girona]] or [[Perpignan]]. He was the second son of King [[Peter IV of Aragon]] and [[Eleanor of Sicily]] (Leonora), princess of the Sicilian [[cadet branch|branch]] of the [[Crown of Aragon|House of Aragon]].Bisson, Thomas N. The Medieval Crown of Aragon: A Short History. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1986. {{ISBN|0-19-821987-3}}. As a cadet prince of the Aragonese royal family, Martin was given the Duchy of Montblanch (modern [[Montblanc, Tarragona|Montblanc]]).His contemporary title was ''duch de Montblanch''. In [[Barcelona]] on 13 June 1373, Martin married [[Maria de Luna|María López de Luna]] (d. [[Villarreal]], 20 December 1406), the daughter and heiress of Lope,{{cite web |last=Marek |first=Miroslav |url=http://genealogy.euweb.cz/barcelona/barcelona2.html |title=Barcelona 2 |accessdate=2008-05-13}}{{Self-published source|date=August 2012}}{{Better source|date=August 2012}} Lord and 1st Count of [[Luna, Zaragoza|Luna]] and Lord of [[Segorbe]] and his wife Brianda de Got, who was born in [[Provence]] and was related to [[Pope Clement V]]. In 1380 his father appointed him lord and [[regent]] of the island of Sicily, then known also as Trinacria, since its queen [[Maria, Queen of Sicily|Maria of Sicily]], who was also Martin's cousin, was underage (Maria's father, [[Frederick III the Simple]], died in 1377). As a son of Eleanor of Sicily, Martin was himself an heir to the island, should Maria's family die out. ==Kingship== In 1396, Martin succeeded his elder brother [[John I of Aragon|John I]], who had died sonless, on the throne of Aragon. However, Sicilian nobles were causing unrest and so Martin was kept in Sicily. Meanwhile, Martin's wife, María López de Luna, claimed the throne on his behalf of and acted as his representative until he arrived in 1397. Still, the delay opened the way for more problems and quarrels to surface in Aragon. His right to the throne was contested, first by Count [[Matthew of Foix]] on behalf of his wife [[Joanna of Aragon, Countess of Foix|Joanna]], elder daughter of John I. However, Martin succeeded in quashing an invasion by troops of the count. After the death of the childless Joanna, John I's younger daughter [[Yolande of Aragon]], who had married the [[House of Valois-Anjou|Angevin]] King [[Louis II of Naples]], continued the claim, as did her sons. Martin launched crusades against the [[Moors]] in [[North Africa]] in 1398 and 1399. Aragon had been trying to subjugate [[Sardinia]] since the reign of [[James II of Aragon|James II]], and gradually the Aragonese had conquered most of the island. However, in the 1380s, during the reign of Martin's father Peter IV, the remaining independent principality of [[Arborea]] became a fortress of rebellion and the Aragonese were rapidly driven back by [[Eleanor of Arborea]], so that practically the whole of Sardinia was lost. King Martin sent his son [[Martin I of Sicily|Martin the Younger]], by then king of Sicily through his marriage to Queen Maria, to reconquer Sardinia. The son won the [[Battle of Sanluri]] (San Luis, San Luigi) in 1409, drove away the [[Genoa|Genoese]] allies of the Sardinians, and subjugated a vast number of Sardinian nobles. This soon caused Arborea's total loss of independence. Soon after the battle, however, Martin the Younger died suddenly, due to malaria. Martin of Aragon then succeeded his son as King of Sicily, taking the title of Martin II. Overall, the Kingdom of Aragon enjoyed external peace during Martin's reign and he worked to quell internal strife caused by nobles, factions and bandits. He supported the [[Western Schism|Avignon line of Popes]] and [[Avignon Pope Benedict XIII|Pope Benedict XIII]], who was Aragonese, held the seat throughout Martin's reign. Martin's military intervention rescued the imprisoned Benedict in 1403 from the clutches of his rivals and the Pope settled in [[Valencia (city in Spain)|Valencia]]'s countryside. == Issue == Martin had four legitimate children by Queen Maria: [[Martin I of Sicily|Martin the Younger]] (b. 1374/1376), James (b. 1378), John (b. 1380), and Margaret (b. 1384/1388). The three younger children all died early, and so after Martin the Younger's death, King Martin appointed his cousin [[James II, Count of Urgell]], the closest legitimate [[agnate]] of the [[House of Barcelona]], as [[Governor-General]] of all the kingdoms of Aragon, a position that belonged traditionally to the heir presumptive. Martin still married secondly on 17 September 1409 to his cousin [[Margaret of Prades]], daughter of Peter of Aragon, Baron of Entenza, but the short marriage was childless. ==Succession== Martin died, in the monastery of Valldonzella, outside the city walls of Barcelona on the 31st of May, 1410. While the reason remains unclear, it is supposed{{by whom|date=June 2018}} that either plague (present in the area at the time), [[Uremia|uremic coma]] (the king suffered from severe obesity that affected his health) or the possibility of having been poisoned, only supported by Renaissance chronicler [[Lorenzo Valla|Valla]].{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} The story of the king's [[Death from laughter|death associated with laughter]] (following a joke told by Borra the jester while Martin was suffering from indigestion) although lacking in historical evidence, has been recorded.{{cite web |last1=Morris |first1=Paul N. |title=Patronage and Piety Montserrat and the Royal House of Medieval Catalonia-Aragon |url=http://www.glossa.fi/mirator/pdf/Morris.pdf |accessdate=24 June 2018 |page=8 |date=October 2000}}{{cite book |last1=Doran |first1=Dr. (John) |title=The History of Court Fools. |date=1858 |publisher=Richard Bently |location=London |pages=317–318 |url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.32044005050901;view=1up;seq=332}} Despite the demands to have an heir declared, the physical incapacity of the king prevented him from giving a clear name, and to the question of giving permission to give to the throne to the person who would be most legitimate for it he gave a terse "Hoc" (Yes).{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} All of Martin's legitimate descendants, born of his marriage with Queen Maria, were already dead, and his second marriage did not produce any children. Only an illegitimate grandson, [[Frederick, Count of Luna]], a natural son of Martin the Younger, and an illegitimate daughter - ineligible for succession due to the rules established during the times of James I the Conqueror - continued the direct line of inheritance. The king, despite his desire and some effort, was unable to obtain sufficient confirmation of Frederick as his successor prior to his death. As a result, Martin's death led to a two-year [[interregnum]], during which at least five contenders for the throne came forward, including Frederick of Luna and James II of Urgell. Succession of the [[Crown of Aragon]] was determined by the [[Compromise of Caspe]] on 28 June 1412, in which Martin's nephew [[Ferdinand I of Aragon|Ferdinand]], [[infante]] of [[Crown of Castile|Castile]] was chosen as the next king, establishing the [[House of Trastámara]]. ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Microbial biogeography''' is a subset of [[biogeography]], a field that concerns the distribution of organisms across space and time.<ref name = "lomolino">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Mark V. Lomolino, Brett R. Riddle, Robert J. Whittaker, James H.|title=Biogeography|date=2010|publisher=Sinauer Associates|location=Sunderland, Mass.|isbn=9780878934942|edition=4th}}</ref> Although biogeography traditionally focused on plants and larger animals, recent studies have broadened this field to include distribution patterns of [[microorganisms]]. This extension of biogeography to smaller scales—known as "microbial biogeography"—is enabled by ongoing advances in genetic technologies.
The aim of microbial biogeography is to reveal where microorganisms live, at what abundance, and why. Microbial biogeography can therefore provide insight into the underlying mechanisms that generate and hinder [[biodiversity]].<ref name = "martiny">{{cite journal|last1=Martiny|first1=Jennifer B. Hughes|last2=Bohannan|first2=Brendan J.M.|last3=Brown|first3=James H.|last4=Colwell|first4=Robert K.|last5=Fuhrman|first5=Jed A.|last6=Green|first6=Jessica L.|last7=Horner-Devine|first7=M. Claire|last8=Kane|first8=Matthew|last9=Krumins|first9=Jennifer Adams|last10=Kuske|first10=Cheryl R.|last11=Morin|first11=Peter J.|last12=Naeem|first12=Shahid|last13=Øvreås|first13=Lise|last14=Reysenbach|first14=Anna-Louise|last15=Smith|first15=Val H.|last16=Staley|first16=James T.|title=Microbial biogeography: putting microorganisms on the map|journal=Nature Reviews Microbiology|date=February 2006|volume=4|issue=2|pages=102–112|doi=10.1038/nrmicro1341|pmid=16415926}}</ref> Microbial biogeography also enables predictions of where certain organisms can survive and how they respond to changing environments, making it applicable to several other fields such as climate change research.

Acad. Imp. Sci. St. Petersb. Ser. VII'' 41, n. 8, 1-201, [https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/176385#page/771/mode/1up BHL].</ref> In 1934, [[Lourens Baas Becking]], based on his own research in California's salt lakes, as well as work by others on salt lakes worldwide,<ref name="Bass1934">Baas-Becking, L.G.M. English translation, 2015, [https://books.google.com/books?id=hx-dCgAAQBAJ].</ref> concluded that "everything is everywhere, but the environment selects".<ref>Translated from the original Dutch: ''"Alles is overal: maar het milieu selecteert"''</ref> Baas Becking attributed the first half of this hypothesis to his colleague [[Martinus Beijerinck]] (1913).<ref name=staley193>Staley, J. T. & Gosink, J. J. (1999). Poles Apart: Biodiversity and Biogeography of Sea Ice Bacteria. ''Annual Review of Microbiology'' 53: 189-215, [http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.micro.53.1.189?journalCode=micro].</ref><ref>Beijerinck, M.W.
